pullRequest.body:
Also moved `Algebra.discr_eq_discr_of_toMatrix_coeff_isIntegral` to `Mathlib/NumberTheory/NumberField/Discriminant.lean`.

---

nodes.body: I did think about this, but `traceFormDualSubmodule` only works for B-middle linear forms (i.e. $\langle ra, b\rangle = \langle a, rb\rangle$), and there isn't a canonical choice of one (`(algebraMap A K).range`) in most cases. Even if both of these were given in as arguments, the results I use below mostly cannot be generalized so I refrained from doing so.

> I did think about this, but `traceFormDualSubmodule` only works for B-middle linear forms (i.e. ⟨ra,b⟩=⟨a,rb⟩), and there isn't a canonical choice of one (`(algebraMap A K).range`) in most cases. Even if both of these were given in as arguments, the results I use below mostly cannot be generalized so I refrained from doing so.

But it is always an `A`-module, right? I just meant that construction (the dual lattice).
I tried a bit, but it only generalizes well in sublattices. Or do you think a definition without much API is enough?

> I tried a bit, but it only generalizes well in sublattices. Or do you think a definition without much API is enough?

I just mean the following: take a ring `A` with field of fraction `K`, and `V` a `K`-vector space with a bilinear form `T`. Let `X` be a sub `A`-module of `V`. Then the set `{v ∈ V such that T(v, w) ∈ A for all w ∈ X}` is a `A`-module. If I am not confused this is your construction, right? In your case it is also a `B`-module.
Yes but I can't prove much about it. I can still add it if that is okay.
This is now ready for review.
The different ideal is the inverse of the dual which needs `IsDedekindDomain` to make sense.

> The different ideal is the inverse of the dual which needs `IsDedekindDomain` to make sense.

I was thinking about a file to define `Iᵛ`, but you're right it is probably not worth it.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7209369820/job/19640173057)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7209369820/job/19640172838)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7209369820/job/19640173299)

Can you try to generalize at least the definition of `traceFormDualSubmodule` as much as possible? For example I don't think it needs `K` to be a field (don't bother about theorems unless the exact same proof works).

Also, I think we want the general version for any (nondegenerate?) bilinear form. I think that a sensible thing to do is to create a `Bilinear` folder (the file `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.BilinearForm` is very long and should be splitted), with this new notion, and then specialize to the trace in the `Different` file. If you do so feel free to ask my review.

Thanks!

LGTM, thanks!

Can you split the file `Mathlib/RingTheory/DedekindDomain/Different.lean` into something like `Mathlib/RingTheory/Different.lean` and `Mathlib/RingTheory/DedekindDomain/Different.lean`? Files are cheap and maybe one day someone will want the different without importing all the stuff about dedekind domains.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion dual A K I = 0 ↔ I = 0 := ⟨not_imp_not.mp dual_ne_zero, fun e ↦ e.symm ▸ dual_zero⟩ ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion dual A K I ≠ 0 ↔ I ≠ 0 := dual_eq_zero_iff.not ```

```suggestion
lemma isIntegral_discr_mul_of_mem_traceFormDualSubmodule
    (I : Submodule B L) {ι} [DecidableEq ι] [Fintype ι]
    {b : Basis ι K L} (hb : ∀ i, IsIntegral A (b i))
    {a x : L} (ha : a ∈ I) (hx : x ∈ Iᵛ) :
    IsIntegral A ((discr K b) • a * x) := by
```
Maybe the name can be changed to allow dot  notation with `Basis`, but I am not sure.
I don't think so, as `b : Basis` is implicit argument, and it is not the main focus of the lemma.

```suggestion
lemma FractionalIdeal.coe_dual {I : FractionalIdeal B⁰ L} (hI : I ≠ 0) :
```

```suggestion
lemma FractionalIdeal.le_dual_inv_aux {I J : FractionalIdeal B⁰ L} (hI : I ≠ 0) (hIJ : I * J ≤ 1) :
```

```suggestion
lemma FractionalIdeal.le_dual_iff {I J : FractionalIdeal B⁰ L} (hJ : J ≠ 0) :
```

```suggestion
lemma FractionalIdeal.dual_mul_self {I : FractionalIdeal B⁰ L} (hI : I ≠ 0) :
```

```suggestion
lemma FractionalIdeal.self_mul_dual {I : FractionalIdeal B⁰ L} (hI : I ≠ 0) :
```
Good idea to move this.
Can you check that `A` and `K` live in different universes than `L` (I don't know exactly what `(A K)` does).
Can you add simple properties like the computation of `⊥ᵛ` and `⊤ᵛ`?

I added `(⊥ : Submodule B L)ᵛ = ⊤`, but for the other one, the best I can get is `(⊤ : Submodule B L)ᵛ = if IsField A then ⊤ else ⊥` under `IsSeparable K L`.
Do we want this?
Ouf, I though `IsSeparable` were enough to get a reasonable answer. As you want, if you've already done it I would say why not.
You can `namespace FractionalIdeal` here. Also `variable {I : FractionalIdeal B⁰ L}` is probably a good idea.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Define the dual of a fractional ideal.

nodes.body:
Can you try to generalize at least the definition of `traceFormDualSubmodule` as much as possible? For example I don't think it needs `K` to be a field (don't bother about theorems unless the exact same proof works).

Also, I think we want the general version for any (nondegenerate?) bilinear form. I think that a sensible thing to do is to create a `Bilinear` folder (the file `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.BilinearForm` is very long and should be splitted), with this new notion, and then specialize to the trace in the `Different` file. If you do so feel free to ask my review.

Thanks!

I did think about this, but `traceFormDualSubmodule` only works for B-middle linear forms (i.e. $\langle ra, b\rangle = \langle a, rb\rangle$), and there isn't a canonical choice of one (`(algebraMap A K).range`) in most cases. Even if both of these were given in as arguments, the results I use below mostly cannot be generalized so I refrained from doing so.

Even if both of these were given in as arguments, the results I use below mostly cannot be generalized so I refrained from doing so.

But it is always an `A`-module, right? I just meant that construction (the dual lattice).
I tried a bit, but it only generalizes well in sublattices. Or do you think a definition without much API is enough?

> I tried a bit, but it only generalizes well in sublattices. Or do you think a definition without much API is enough?

I just mean the following: take a ring `A` with field of fraction `K`, and `V` a `K`-vector space with a bilinear form `T`. Let `X` be a sub `A`-module of `V`. Then the set `{v ∈ V such that T(v, w) ∈ A for all w ∈ X}` is a `A`-module. If I am not confused this is your construction, right? In your case it is also a `B`-module.
Yes but I can't prove much about it. I can still add it if that is okay.
This is now ready for review.

LGTM, thanks!

Can you split the file `Mathlib/RingTheory/DedekindDomain/Different.lean` into something like `Mathlib/RingTheory/Different.lean` and `Mathlib/RingTheory/DedekindDomain/Different.lean`? Files are cheap and maybe one day someone will want the different without importing all the stuff about dedekind domains.
The different ideal is the inverse of the dual which needs `IsDedekindDomain` to make sense.

I was thinking about a file to define `Iᵛ`, but you're right it is probably not worth it.

Thanks!
